title-group.article-title: EULER—MACLAURIN EXPANSIONS FOR INTEGRALS WITH ARBITRARY ALGEBRAIC ENDPOINT SINGULARITIES

abstract.p: In this paper, we provide the Euler—Maclaurin expansions for (offset) trapezoidal rule approximations of the divergent finite-range integrals ${\mathrm{f}}_{\mathrm{a}}^{\mathrm{b}}\mathrm{f}\left(\mathrm{x}\right)\mathrm{d}\mathrm{x}$ , where f ∈ C ∞ (a,b) but can have arbitrary algebraic singularities at one or both endpoints. We assume that f(x) has asymptotic expansions of the general forms $\begin{array}{c}\mathrm{f}\left(\mathrm{x}\right)\sim \mathrm{K}(\mathrm{x}-\mathrm{a})^{-1}+\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}{\mathrm{c}}_{\mathrm{s}}(\mathrm{x}-\mathrm{a})^{_{\gamma }\mathrm{s}} \quad \mathrm{a}\mathrm{s} \ x\rightarrow a+,\\ \mathrm{f}\left(\mathrm{x}\right)\sim \mathrm{L}(\mathrm{b}-\mathrm{x})^{-1}+\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}{\mathrm{d}}_{\mathrm{s}}(\mathrm{b}-\mathrm{x})^{_{\delta }\mathrm{s}} \quad \mathrm{a}\mathrm{s} \ x\rightarrow b-,\end{array}$ where K, L, and c s , d s , s = 0,1,..., are some constants, ǀKǀ + ǀLǀ ≠ 0, and γ s and δ s are distinct, arbitrary and, in general, complex, and different from -1, and satisfy $\Re \gamma _{0}\leq \Re \gamma _{1}\leq \cdots,\lim_{s \rightarrow \infty}\Re \gamma _{s} = +\infty; \quad \Re \delta _{0}\leq \Re \delta _{1}\leq \cdots,\lim_{s \rightarrow \infty}\Re \delta _{s} = +\infty$ . Hence the integral ${\mathrm{f}}_{\mathrm{a}}^{\mathrm{b}}\mathrm{f}\left(\mathrm{x}\right)\mathrm{d}\mathrm{x}$ exists in the sense of Hadamard finite part. The results we obtain in this work extend some of the results in [A. Sidi, Numer. Math. 98 (2004), pp. 371—387] that pertain to the cases in which K = L = 0. They are expressed in very simple terms based only on the asymptotic expansions of f(x) as x → a+ and x → b-. With h = (b - a)/n, where n is a positive integer, one of these results reads $h\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f(a+ih)\sim I[f]+K(C-\mathrm{log} \ h)+\sum_{s=0_{\gamma_{s} \notin \{2,4,\cdots\}}}^{\infty} c_{s}\zeta(-\gamma_{s})h^{\gamma_{s}+1} + L(C-\mathrm{log} \ h)+\sum_{s=0_{\delta_{s} \notin \{2,4,\cdots\}}}^{\infty} d_{s}\zeta(-\delta_{s})h^{\delta_{s}+1} \quad as \ h \rightarrow 0,$ where I[f] is the Hadamard finite part of ${\mathrm{f}}_{\mathrm{a}}^{\mathrm{b}}\mathrm{f}\left(\mathrm{x}\right)\mathrm{d}\mathrm{x}$ , C is Euler's constant and ζ(z) is the Riemann Zeta function. We illustrate the results with an example.
